column1: Laconia is named after the Greek region of Laconia  (Greek: Λακωνία
column3: Greek pronunciation: [lakoˈni.a]) in the southeastern part of the Peloponnese peninsula. The word "laconic" is derived from the name of the region by analogy—to speak in a concise way
column4: as the Spartans were reputed by the Athenians to do.

column1: A large Abenaki Indian settlement called Acquadocton Village once existed at the point now known as The Weirs
column2: named by colonists for fishing weirs discovered at the outlet of the Winnipesaukee River. Early explorers had hoped to follow the Piscataqua River north to Lake Champlain in search of the great lakes and rivers of Canada mentioned in Indian folklore. About 1652
column3: the Endicott surveying party visited the area
column4: an event commemorated by Endicott Rock
column5: a local landmark.  A fort would be built at Laconia in 1746. But ongoing hostilities between the English
column7: and their respective Native American allies prevented settlement until 1761
column8: after which it remained for many years a part of Meredith and Gilford called Meredith Bridge.

column2: lumber and grist mills were established on Mill Street
column3: with taverns built soon thereafter on Parade Street.  About 1822

column6: the Belknap Mill was built to manufacture textiles; in operation by 1828
column7: the structure is today a museum listed on the National Register of Historic Places and is the oldest unaltered brick textile mill in the country. Local industry produced lumber
column11: knitting machinery and needles. But the city's largest employer would be the Laconia Car Company
column13: trolley and subway cars. Started in 1848
column14: it lasted until the 1930s. The railroad entered town in 1849
column15: carrying both freight and an increasing number of summer tourists to popular Weirs Beach.

column2: Laconia was incorporated as a town from land in Meredith Bridge
column3: Lakeport
column4: Weirs and part of Gilmanton. The name was probably derived from the old Laconia Company
column5: formed by Captain John Mason and the Masonian Proprietors to sell parcels of land during the colonial era. The Great Fire of 1860 destroyed most of Main Street from Mill to Water streets
column6: followed by the Great Lakeport Fire of 1903
column7: a blaze so fierce that fire companies were brought by train from as far away as Dover. Laconia was incorporated as a city in 1893.

column1: Laconia is located northwest of the geographic center of Belknap County. The city lies at the center of New Hampshire's Lakes Region
column2: and all or part of four major bodies of water lie within its limits: Lake Winnipesaukee
column3: Winnisquam Lake
column4: Opechee Bay and Paugus Bay (sometimes counted as an arm of Winnipesaukee
column5: but historically a separate body of water).

column1: Laconia contains three main villages. Downtown Laconia
column2: where the Belknap County Courthouse is located
column3: can be found in the southern tip of the city
column4: along the Winnipesaukee River between Opechee Bay to the north and Winnisquam Lake to the southwest. Lakeport
column5: located between Opeechee Bay and Paugus Bay
column6: is near the geographic center of the city. Weirs Beach
column7: around the channel connecting Paugus Bay with Lake Winnipesaukee
column8: lies at the northern edge of the city.

column1: U.S. Route 3 passes through parts of the city
column2: bypassing downtown but passing through Weirs Beach. New Hampshire Route 11 bypasses the city in a concurrency with US 3. The two highways lead southwest from Laconia to Tilton and Franklin. New Hampshire Route 11A represents the old routes 11 and 3 through downtown as Court Street and Union Avenue
column3: but then turns east on Gilford Avenue to lead to Gilford and West Alton. New Hampshire Route 106 runs north-south through downtown
column4: leading south to Concord and north to Meredith. New Hampshire Route 107 leads southeast from downtown towards Gilmanton and Pittsfield. Route 107 turns north in downtown and follows Union Avenue (former Route 3) to a junction with US 3 near the north end of the Laconia Bypass. US 3 continues north along the east shore of Paugus Bay
column5: through Weirs Beach and into Meredith. Route 11 leads east from the Laconia Bypass past Glendale and into Alton. New Hampshire Route 11B leads east from Wei into Gilford.

column1: The former Boston and Maine Railroad White Mountain Branch
column3: Concord & Montreal Railroad
column4: enters Laconia at the Belmont town line near Lake Winnisquam and runs north through the city
column5: through Lakeport and along Paugus Bay to Weirs Beach and Meredith. Purchased by the State of New Hampshire in 1975
column6: the tracks are actively used for freight purposes by the New England Southern Railroad and for tourist train service by the Plymouth & Lincoln Railroad between Meredith and Lakeport
column7: with occasional service out of Laconia. The line is also a vital active link to the National rail network for the tourist operator to ship and receive equipment for their own use and also to perform contract work at the railroad's Lincoln repair shops.Laconia Municipal Airport is located just east of the city limits in Gilford.A recreational trail called the W.O.W. Trail (Winnipesaukee–Opechee–Winnisquam) links several parts of the city
column8: following the railroad tracks from Winnisquam Lake
column10: and running to Lakeport. A desire to extend the trail to Weirs Beach has been contested by residents in private communities abutting the rail corridor. The proposed removal of active rail for said extension is contested also by railroad companies actively using the tracks and the State of New Hampshire Bureau of Rail and Transit.According to the United States Census Bureau
column11: the city has a total area of 26.6 square miles (68.8 km2)
column12: of which 20.0 square miles (51.9 km2) are land and 6.5 square miles (16.9 km2) are water
column13: comprising 24.54% of the city. Laconia is drained by the Winnipesaukee River. It is bounded in the southwest by Winnisquam Lake
column14: and by Lake Winnipesaukee in the northeast. Laconia lies fully within the Merrimack River watershed. The highest point in Laconia is a 960-foot (290 m) hill in the northern part of the city
column15: west of Paugus Bay's Pickerel Cove and just east of Route 106.

column1: Laconia is governed by a mayor-council and city manager system. The Mayor and council are elected in a citywide vote
column2: while the city manager is hired by the council. The council consists of six members who are elected from the six single-member wards.

column3: represented by Republican Harold F. French. On the New Hampshire Executive Council

column1: Laconia is home to the Winnipesaukee Muskrats of the New England Collegiate Baseball League (NECBL).  The franchise began play in 2010 at Robbie Mills Field in Laconia.
